description: From Middle English waven, from Old English wafian (‚Äúto wave, fluctuate, waver in mind, wonder‚Äù), from Proto-West Germanic *wabbjan, from Proto-Germanic *wab≈çnƒÖ, *wabjanƒÖ (‚Äúto wander, sway‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *web ∞- (‚Äúto move to and from, wander‚Äù).
Cognate with Middle High German waben (‚Äúto wave‚Äù), German wabern (‚Äúto waft‚Äù), Icelandic v√°fa (‚Äúto fluctuate, waver, doubt‚Äù). See also waver.

verbs.description: wave (third-person singular simple present waves, present participle waving, simple past and past participle waved)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move back and forth repeatedly and somewhat loosely.
examples: The flag waved in the gentle breeze.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move one‚Äôs hand back and forth (generally above the shoulders) in greeting or departure.
(transitive, metonymically) To call attention to, or give a direction or command to, by a waving motion, as of the hand; to signify by waving; to beckon; to signal; to indicate.
examples: She spoke, and bowing waved / Dismissal.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To have an undulating or wavy form.
(transitive) To raise into inequalities of surface; to give an undulating form or surface to.
(transitive) To produce waves to the hair.
(intransitive, baseball) To swing and miss at a pitch.
(transitive) To cause to move back and forth repeatedly.
examples: The starter waved the flag to begin the race.

entries.meaning: (transitive, metonymically) To signal (someone or something) with a waving movement.
(intransitive, obsolete) To fluctuate; to waver; to be in an unsettled state.
(intransitive, ergative) To move like a wave, or by floating; to waft.

description: From Middle English *wave, partially from waven (‚Äúto fluctuate, wave‚Äù) (see above) and partially from Middle English wawe, waghe (‚Äúwave‚Äù), from Old English w«£g (‚Äúa wave, billow, motion, water, flood, sea‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *wƒìgaz (‚Äúmotion, storm, wave‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *we«µ ∞- (‚Äúto drag, carry‚Äù). Cognate with North Frisian weage (‚Äúwave, flood, sea‚Äù), German Woge (‚Äúwave‚Äù), French vague (‚Äúwave‚Äù) (from Germanic), Gothic êçÖêå¥êå≤êçÉ (wƒìgs, ‚Äúa wave‚Äù). See also waw.

entries.meaning: A moving disturbance in the level of a body of liquid; an undulation.
examples: The wave traveled from the center of the lake before breaking on the shore.

entries.meaning: (poetic) The ocean.
examples: [‚Ä¶]  your father Murtagh Ross, and his lawful childless wife, Dionaid, and his sister Anna‚Äîone and all, they lie beneath the green wave or in the brown mould.

entries.meaning: (physics) A moving disturbance in the energy level of a field.
examples: Gravity waves, while predicted by theory for decades, have been notoriously difficult to detect.

entries.meaning: A shape that alternatingly curves in opposite directions.
examples: Her hair had a nice wave to it.

entries.meaning: Any of a number of species of moths in the geometrid subfamily Sterrhinae, which have wavy markings on the wings.
A loose back-and-forth movement, as of the hands.
examples: He dismissed her with a wave of the hand.

entries.meaning: (figuratively) A sudden, but temporary, uptick in something.
examples: A wave of shoppers stampeded through the door when the store opened for its Christmas discount special.
A wave of retirees began moving to the coastal area.
A wave of emotion overcame her when she thought about her son who was killed in battle.

entries.meaning: (video games, by extension) One of the successive swarms of enemies sent to attack the player in certain games.
(usually "the wave") A group activity in a crowd imitating a wave going through water, where people in successive parts of the crowd stand and stretch upward, then sit.

verbs.description: wave (third-person singular simple present waves, present participle waving, simple past and past participle waved)

entries.meaning: To generate a wave.

verbs.description: wave (third-person singular simple present waves, present participle waving, simple past and past participle waved)

entries.meaning: Obsolete spelling of waive
